questions.question: Which scholar predicted in 1938 that William Stern's personalistic view would eventually 'have its day' despite running counter to American thought at the time?

answerOptions.text: Gordon W. Allport
answerOptions.rationale: Allport was a Harvard professor who knew Stern personally and admired his work, forecasting its future relevance.

answerOptions.text: Hermann Ebbinghaus
answerOptions.rationale: This individual was actually Stern's mentor who held a mechanistic view that Stern largely opposed.

answerOptions.text: Wilhelm Dilthey
answerOptions.rationale: Though his ideas were compatible with Stern's, he was an older contemporary whose tuition Stern ruefully admitted he did not fully utilize.

answerOptions.text: Wolfgang Köhler
answerOptions.rationale: He was a contemporary associated with Gestalt psychology, which shared some holistic similarities but was not the source of this specific quote.

questions.hint: Consider a prominent Harvard psychologist known for personality theory who was a contemporary of Stern.

questions.question: What technical term did Stern prefer to use instead of 'parts' to describe the facets of a person's functioning?

answerOptions.text: Elements
answerOptions.rationale: Stern specifically avoided this term because it implies that these units exist independently prior to the whole.

answerOptions.text: Moments
answerOptions.rationale: Stern chose this term (Momente) to emphasize that these facets are inherent to the whole and do not exist independently of the person.

answerOptions.text: Components
answerOptions.rationale: Like 'parts,' this word suggests a mechanical assembly of discrete items, which Stern's holism rejected.

answerOptions.text: Quanta
answerOptions.rationale: This term is associated with the natural science/mechanistic perspective that Stern critiqued as impersonal.

questions.hint: Think of a word that suggests a temporary or integrated aspect of a continuous whole rather than a physical piece.

questions.question: According to Critical Personalism, what is the fundamental difference between a 'person' and a 'thing'?

answerOptions.text: A person is a goal-oriented, inherently valuable unity, while a thing is not.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern defined a person as a self-activated being with intrinsic value, whereas a thing is merely an aggregate of parts without such unity.

answerOptions.text: A person is made of psychological content, while a thing is made only of atoms.
answerOptions.rationale: This reflects the mechanistic view Stern opposed; he believed persons are psychophysically neutral, not just psychological.

answerOptions.text: A person can be measured and predicted, while a thing acts randomly.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern argued that things follow blind mechanical laws while persons act with purpose, or teleology.

answerOptions.text: A person is a collection of traits, while a thing is a collection of properties.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern viewed traits as 'ossified' dispositions and believed the person is ontologically prior to any collection of traits.

questions.hint: Focus on the concepts of purpose, unity, and intrinsic value.

questions.question: Which Aristotelian concept did Stern adopt to describe the unitary, goal-striving causality found in human beings?

answerOptions.text: Efficient Cause
answerOptions.rationale: While relevant to physical science, Stern felt this alone was insufficient to understand personal development and purpose.

answerOptions.text: Entelechy
answerOptions.rationale: Stern used this term to represent a scientifically defensible teleology where human actions are guided by goals.

answerOptions.text: Tabula Rasa
answerOptions.rationale: This concept suggests the mind is a blank slate, which contradicts Stern's view on inner dispositions and potentialities.

answerOptions.text: Catharsis
answerOptions.rationale: This is a concept related to emotional release in drama and later psychoanalysis, not Stern's theory of causality.

questions.hint: The term relates to a being having its purpose or end-goal within itself.

questions.question: Stern's thesis of 'psychophysical neutrality' implies that:

answerOptions.text: The mind and body are two separate entities that interact constantly.
answerOptions.rationale: This describes 'naïve personalism' or dualism, which Stern distinguished from his own critical perspective.

answerOptions.text: Psychological processes are entirely reducible to physical brain states.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a reductive mechanistic view that Stern explicitly rejected throughout his career.

answerOptions.text: The whole person is the primary fact, and the distinction between physical and mental is secondary.
answerOptions.rationale: Psychophysical neutrality posits that the person functions as a unity, with 'body' and 'mind' being different facets of that same unity.

answerOptions.text: Environmental factors are more important than biological factors in development.
answerOptions.rationale: This ignores Stern's core idea of 'convergence,' which balances inner dispositions with outer influences.

questions.hint: Consider which level of analysis—the whole or the parts—Stern believed was most important.

questions.question: In the context of goal systems, what is 'introception'?

answerOptions.text: The rejection of all external social goals to preserve the individual self.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern believed a person who only pursues individual goals would be an 'empty point'; introception is about integration, not rejection.

answerOptions.text: The passive acceptance of societal rules without critical thought.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern viewed introception as an active and purposive process, not a passive one.

answerOptions.text: The process of appropriating external goals and forming them according to one's own self.
answerOptions.rationale: Introception allows a person to embody outer goals (heterotelic) without losing their unique personality or becoming a mere tool.

answerOptions.text: The psychological defense mechanism used to hide one's true intentions.
answerOptions.rationale: This sounds like a Freudian concept; Stern's term specifically relates to the dynamic adjustment of personal goals.

questions.hint: Think about how a person makes external values or purposes their own.

questions.question: How did the Sterns define 'pseudo-lies' in children?

answerOptions.text: Lies that are told habitually and require professional intervention.
answerOptions.rationale: Chronic or pathological lying is different from pseudo-lies, which are common and developmental.

answerOptions.text: Statements that are factually false but made without the intention to deceive.
answerOptions.rationale: The Sterns argued that without the 'intention to deceive,' a false statement—such as in playful fantasy—cannot be a genuine lie.

answerOptions.text: Untruths told by adults that children are recruited to repeat.
answerOptions.rationale: While children may imitate adult lies, 'pseudo-lie' specifically refers to statements lacking deceptive intent.

answerOptions.text: Lies told by children to gain a material reward.
answerOptions.rationale: Seeking a reward involves an intent to deceive the person giving the reward, making it a genuine lie by Stern's definition.

questions.hint: This term involves a lack of one of the two necessary criteria for a 'genuine' lie.

questions.question: According to Stern's theory of convergence, what are 'inner dispositions'?

answerOptions.text: Fixed traits that determine behavior regardless of the environment.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern explicitly rejected the idea of fixed, mechanistic traits, viewing them instead as something that develops over time.

answerOptions.text: Potentialities whose realization depends on what is afforded by the external world.
answerOptions.rationale: Convergence is the interaction where inner possibilities (potentialities) meet outer influences to shape development.

answerOptions.text: Socially learned habits that replace biological instincts.
answerOptions.rationale: Dispositions are internal to the person, though they converge with the social world; they are not merely learned habits.

answerOptions.text: Universal psychological laws that apply to all humans equally.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern's personalism focuses on the unique individual rather than general laws that ignore personal variation.

questions.hint: Think of these as 'possibilities' rather than 'fixed destiny'.

questions.question: When a person adjusts themselves to the goals of a collective, such as a family or religious congregation, Stern calls this adjustment:

answerOptions.text: Autotelic
answerOptions.rationale: Autotelic refers to a person's own self-maintenance or self-development goals.

answerOptions.text: Syntelic
answerOptions.rationale: This term specifically refers to adjusting to the goals of another individual person.

answerOptions.text: Hypertelic
answerOptions.rationale: Hypertelic adjustment involves supra-personal entities, meaning groups or collectives larger than the individual.

answerOptions.text: Ideotelic
answerOptions.rationale: This adjustment relates to broad human ideals like truth, beauty, or justice.

questions.hint: The prefix here suggests something that is 'above' or 'beyond' a single individual.

questions.question: Why did Stern argue that Critical Personalism is NOT a form of individualism?

answerOptions.text: Because it claims that the individual has no rights compared to the state.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern also distanced himself from 'socialism' where individual freedom is choked; he sought a middle ground.

answerOptions.text: Because it ignores individual differences in favor of general group dynamics.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern was highly interested in individual uniqueness, but believed that uniqueness is tied to social responsibility.

answerOptions.text: Because it emphasizes that persons have duties to their society and that development occurs within a social milieu.
answerOptions.rationale: Stern believed that individuals have an 'ethics of ability' to serve the community and that they are accountable to societal values.

answerOptions.text: Because it focuses only on the physical atoms that make up a person.
answerOptions.rationale: This is the 'impersonal' mechanistic view that Stern spent his career fighting against.

questions.hint: Consider Stern's 'ethics of ability' and the idea that 'it takes a village'.

questions.question: Which major event in 1934 forced William Stern and his wife Clara to leave Germany for the United States?

answerOptions.text: The start of World War I
answerOptions.rationale: Stern actually relocated to Hamburg during the midst of World War I in 1916, not 1934.

answerOptions.text: The publication of the third volume of 'Person and Thing'
answerOptions.rationale: This volume was published in 1924, a decade before his departure.

answerOptions.text: Persecution by the Nazi regime
answerOptions.rationale: As Jewish scholars, the Sterns fled Nazi Germany in 1934, leading William to take a position at Duke University.

answerOptions.text: An invitation to lead the Psychology Department at Harvard
answerOptions.rationale: While he was admired by Allport at Harvard, Stern accepted a faculty position at Duke University in North Carolina.

questions.hint: This event involved a political and racial purge of German universities in the early 1930s.

questions.question: Which specific project did Stern credit with sharpening his personalistic convictions and protecting him from 'ivory-tower schemes'?

answerOptions.text: His laboratory experiments with Hermann Ebbinghaus
answerOptions.rationale: While he appreciated Ebbinghaus's experimental approach, it was the mechanistic side of it he sought to counter.

answerOptions.text: A three-volume series on the 'Philosophy of Value'
answerOptions.rationale: This was the result of his theoretical work, not the specific project that provided the foundational observations.

answerOptions.text: An 18-year diary project observing the development of his three children
answerOptions.rationale: Observing the 'unitary life course' of his children Hilde, Günther, and Eva provided the concrete data for his theory of personal causality.

answerOptions.text: His collaboration with Gestalt psychologists in Berlin
answerOptions.rationale: Stern critiqued Gestalt psychology for potentially becoming another form of 'elementalism' if it ignored the person.

questions.hint: This project was initiated shortly after the birth of his first daughter, Hilde, in 1900.
